Title: Linear Regression
Summary: Linear regression is a statistical method used to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. It assumes that this relationship is linear, meaning that a change in the independent variable(s) corresponds to a proportional change in the dependent variable. Linear regression aims to find the best-fitting linear equation that describes this relationship, allowing for prediction and understanding of the data.

Advantages.Simplicity: Linear regression is a straightforward and easy-to-understand method. It provides a simple, interpretable model of the data.
Advantages.Interpretability: The coefficients of the linear equation provide insights into the strength and direction of the relationships between variables.
Advantages.Quick Computation: Linear regression can be computed relatively quickly, making it suitable for large datasets.
Advantages.Versatility: It can be used for both simple and complex problems and can be extended to multiple regression for more complex relationships.
Advantages.Baseline Model: It often serves as a baseline model for comparison with more advanced machine learning algorithms.

Disadvantages.Assumption of Linearity: Linear regression assumes a linear relationship between variables, which may not hold for all real-world data.
Disadvantages.Sensitivity to Outliers: Linear regression is sensitive to outliers, and extreme data points can strongly influence the model.
Disadvantages.Underfitting: In cases of complex relationships, linear regression may underfit the data, leading to poor predictions.
Disadvantages.Limited to Continuous Variables: It is primarily suitable for continuous variables and may not handle categorical or non-linear data well.
Disadvantages.Model Complexity: Linear regression cannot capture intricate relationships present in many real-world scenarios.
